dangerous as the animal with the same name.

OPINIONS of the PRESS.
W e say of M r . Dion Bourcicault's Comedy of • Old
Heads and Young H e a r t s ' produced last night, t h a t it is t h «
moat amusing five-act production that has been seen for years,
and t h a t i t has pleased—honestly pleased, the public t o a d e gree t h a t may defy the exertions of any opposing theorist t o
dispute i t s claim to popularity. His piece is carefully written
throughout, and he has introduced points in his dialogue, which
are worthy of any author. T h e author has thrown himself
with full zeal upon his writing, and has pushed along the dialogue with a buoyancy of spirit, liveliness, and brilliancy, which
completely carry an audience along in spite of themselves.
T h e curtain descended amid a perfect roar of applause. N o
drama could have been more successful, and we must say t h e
success was fully deserved. T h e author h a s produced a work
t h a t has more elements of popularity t h a n any of equal length
t h a t we have seen for a long, long time. T h e actors played as
well as t h e most fidgetty dramatist could desire, and the decorative p a r t has been m o s t liberally managed by Mr. W e b s t e r ,
who received a marked acknowledgment on his entrance.—
The Times, and Weekly
Chronicle.
H e r e we have a Comedy of real English g r o w t h , and with
a right hearty old E n g l i s h title. W e m u s t now, in j u s t i c e ,
record t h e n o less palpable merit of the author—his dialogue
in which h e , with an affluence almost reckless, dispenses
antithesis, repartee, metaphor, simile, and pathos, with a
facility a n d a brilliancy that awakened many an echo of
boisterous laughter mid hearty applause ; nothing interrupted
the continuous explosions of laughter a n d plaudits which
reached their climax when M r . Farren upon joining the h a n d s
of the lovers, uttered the following valedictory lines, with u
t o u c h i n g tenderness and truth which found their response in
every b r e a s t : — " B l e s s y o u r y o u n g faces." &<>.
T h e comedy
w a | very equally acted.—Morning Post,
A p p l a u s e and laughter were Irequent during the evening,
and the curtain fell amid a hurricane of cheers. Every scene
contains some unexpected turn, ingeniously contrived. T h e r e
is considerable advunce for the better in the tone of this
comedy.
T h e comedy is put splendidly upon the s t a g e , and
nothing, in short, has been spared in t h e way of scenic
embellishment.—Morning Herald.
It may run for a season or t w o , and even, we admit b e very
popular. T h e r e is much that is striking and brilliant in t h e
dialogue of this plav. T h e scenery we must not omil to state,
was most g o r g e o u s . Seldom indeed have we seen a n y t h i n g
on flie s t a g e more petfect than the laying o u t of the d r a w i n g
room of Lord Pompion.—Morning chronicle, & Standard.
Mr. W e b s t e r has produced a pood and successful comedy.
" Old H e a d s and Young H e a r t s h a s met with the most full
and decided success. •' Old H e a d s and Y o u n g Hearts" is a
pleasing a n d promising title, and fortunately it does not
promise more than is performed. W h a t we like about this
play is, t h a t it does not partake of the heartless tone of t h e
mongrel, frivolous kino of drama which w e have half-borrowed, half-imitnted, from t h e French. T h e r e is a gTMt
deal of g o o d English " h e a r t " in it, which does not heat exclusively in the y o u n g bosoms of the piece ; for t h e y o u n g e s t
heart (that is, the warmest) a m o n g them all ia conjoined with
the oldest head, in the person of Mr. Rural, the country Clerg y m a n — a sketch in which sweetness, pathos, and humour a r e
combined in a manner worthy of Goldsmith. Excellent dialogue, solid as well us brilliant, smart, playful, satirical, and
indicating knowledge of human nature. T h i s play deceives
its succes.—Jo/iti liull.
Bourcicault's comedy is drawing capital h o u s e s , and m o r e over it deserves to draw them. W e saw it on t h e first and o n
t h e fourth n i g h t s , and it was astonishing t o witness the improvement that has been m a d e in that short interval. N o t only
were ajl t h e performers a t h o m e in their characters, b u t s a m e
small pieces had been cut out which were evident excrescences, and the dialogue ran with unusual spirit and closeness of
repartee. W e are sure that it will he a lasting favorite with
p l a y - g o e r s , and we rejoice to see them so n u m e r o u s . S o m e
h a v e complained that the two last acts are not quite so good
as t h e t h r e e first; we dispute the position, but it is of course
necessary t o g i v e a n author a little time t o unwind the intricacies of his plot, and the plot of the new comedy is here and
there considerably involved. W o d o not scruple t o say that it
is p e r h a p s t h e best eomedv of modern times.and we only w o n der t h a t it did not gain W e b s t e r ' s prize of £'500.—Observer.
Mr. B o u r c i c a u l f s new comedy, " Old H e a d s and Y o u n g
H e a r t s , " was decidedly and deservedly successful. I t is a
legitimate comedy, full of situation, equivoque, and fun, with
a very smart and lively dialogue, a little sentiment, and a g o o d
deal of wit. I t never flags for a moment, and when it is over
j o u say that it will quite bear b e i n g seen again.—Age & Argus.
,y»-»

_

W e would fain h a r e a proof now and t h e n that invention,
constructive power, wit, repartee, have not yet wholly deserted
t h e young writers of E n g l a n d ; and sometimes, though a t l o n g
intervals, we have evidence t h a t these qualities are yet t o b e
found. T h e y are all to be found, for instance, in t h e C o m e d y
o f ' ' Old Heads and Young H e a r t s , " from t h e pen of M r . D .
Bourcicault, produced last night a t this T h e a t r e , and as a consequence, it was completely successful. T h e dialogue is free
and flowing, sprightly, and a t n o time dull. Only premising
farther that the applause was warm and coidial during the first
act, that it was well and equally sustained throughout the other
three, and came to a close with enthusiasm at the e n d of t h e
fifth. T h e piece is admirably b r o u g h t o u t ; t h e scenery is e x cellent—those of the boudoir and t h e suite of drawing-rooma
are perfect in their way. Altogether its success must b e gratifying both t o the author and t h e management. T h e performers were called before the curtain to receive the applause of t h e
audience for their efforts, and were (hanked by the cheers of a
house crowded t o excess.—Sun,
T h e acting of this Comedy deserves a particular notice.—•
Dramatic and Musical
Review.
A more perfect triumph could not b e coveted by author or
manager, surrounded by n galaxy of talent of which no o t h e r
boards can boast, to the achievement of a g r a n d and permanent
success. T o g e t h e r with the public we cordially rejoice t h a t
this successful play has fallen into the hands of Mr. W e b s t e r ,
who deserved the best specimen of the legitimate drama, not
only for his industry in forcing, b u t for his supplying such a
hot-house of artistic talent t o acclimatise t h e plants of British
genius. May our hearts e\ cr be y o u n g e n o u g h , and our h e a d s
never t o o old, t o relish t h e fruit of g o o d writing and g o o d
a c t i n g conjoined in the new comedy at the Haymnrket.—-Era.
H A Y M A R K E T . — " O l d H e a d s a n d Y o u n g "Hearts," (from
t h e pen of Bourcicault), which m a d e its entree to public life
at the Haymarki t T h e a t r e , on Inst Monday evening, with a
d e g r e e of eclat that must have satisfied author, m a n a g e r ,
actors, and every person interested in its success. T h e sparkling fire of repartee, and variety of incident, never allowed t h e
attention of the audience t o be withdrawn for a moment. I t
commences well, and proceeds through the g r e a t e r part of t h e
three first acts with remarkable ease and increasing i n t e r e s t ;
at the commencement of t h e fourth act the author threw in a
fresh stock of embarrassments and mistakes, which tho c o n cluding scene of the fifth a c t triumphantly r e d e e m s , and t h e
curtain descends amidst a torrent of we 1 ! deserved applause.
T h e characters of the comedy are «l! I'rawn with vigour, and
some of them with g r e a t originality. W e have b u t rarely
witnessed a scone on the singe so replete with natural p a t h o s
as that in which Tom discovers that Lady Alice loves his
brother. T h e piece had full just.ee done to it by all the p e r formers ; the mise en scene, too, was in choice taste. T h e suite
ol drawing-rooms in Lord Poinpiott's house, with the a s s e m bled company, was a beautiful and perfect realisation of the
subject in all its purls. T h e applause at the fall of (he curtain was must enthusiastic.—SunJay 'limes.
" Old H e a d s and Young H e a r t s " was triumphantly' s u c c e s s ful, and went with roais of applause from b e g i n n i n g t o e n d .
1 h e comedy will run as long, and prove as great, a favorite a s
Mr. Bnurcicault's first production, " London Assurance."—
Railway
Bell.
" Old H e a d s and Y o u n g H e a r t s " is t h e very best thing that
has appeared for years—an assertion possibly b o r n e . U t by its
triumphant success. T h e writing was sparkling and p u n g e n t ;
the portrayal of character natural and unaffected ; and m t h e
scenes of society introduced, nothing was outraged by i g n o rance of t h e class from which they were drawn. T h e comedy
w e n t with continued bursts of c h e e r i n g , until t h e curtain fell
amidst a whirlwind of applause.—IIlustrafed London News.
A more warm a n d sincere impulse than that which, a t t h e
fall of the curtain on Monday night, actuated a crowded h o u s e
in successively calling forth t h e author, the m a n a g e r , and t h e
performers, could not have been wished for by each and a l l . —
Great Gun.
T h e play opens with g r e a t spirit, and the whole of tbe first
a c t , amid all the difficulty of introducing the characters, is e x cellent. T h e second,thud and fourth acts ensue,and are marked
t h r o u g h o u t by a number of very smart Sayings and pithy o b servations, which would do credit to the true class of comedy,
and were deservedly taken a n d much a p p l a u d e d . — Literaru
Gaxette.
*
W e congratulate M r . W e b s t e r on his n e w piece of " O l d
H e a d s and Y o u n g H e a r t s , a n d M r . Bourcicault upon t h e
triumph he has achieved ; certain it is that it is very clever
and something more—it is very successful.—Dispatch.

OPINIONS of the PRESS.
We say of Mr. Dion Bourcicault's Comedy of ' Old
Heads and Young Hearts' produced last night, tliat it is the
most amusing five-act production that has been seen for years,
and that it has pleased—honestly pleased, the public to a degree that may defy the exertions of any opposing theorist to
dispute its claim to popularity. His piece is carefully written
throughout, and he has introduced points in his dialogue, which
are worthy of any author. The author has thrown himself
with full zeal upon his writing, and has pushed along the dialogue with a buoyancy of spirit, liveliness, and brilliancy, which
completely carry an audience along in spite of themselves.
The curtain descended amid a perfect roar of applause. No
drama could have been more successful, and we must say the
success was fully deserved. The author has produced a work
that has more elements of popularity than any of equal length
that we have seen for a long, long time. The actors played as
well as the most fidgetty dramatist could desire, and the decorative part has been most liberally managed by Mr. Webster,
•who received a marked acknowledgment on his entrance.—
The Times, and Weekly Chronicle.
Here we have a Comedy of real English growth, and with
a right hearty old English title. W e must now, in justice,
record the no less palpable merit of the author—his dialogue
in which he, with an affluence almost reckless, dispenses
antithesis, repartee, metaphor, simile, and pathos, with a
facility and a brilliancy that awakened many an echo of
boisterous laughter and hearty applause; nothing interrupted
the continuous explosions of laughter and plaudits which
reached their climax when Mr. Farren upon joining the hands
of the lovers, uttered the following valedictory lines, with a
touching tenderness and truth which found their response in
every breast:—"Bless your young faces." &c. The comedy
was Very equalTy acted.—Morning Post,
Applause and laughter were frequent during tho evening,
and the curtain fell amid a hurricane of cheers. Every scene
contains some unexpected turn, ingeniously contrived. There
is considerable advance for the better in the tone of this
comedy. The comedy is put splendidly upon the stage, and
nothing, in short, hns been spared in the way of scenic
embellishment.—Morning Herald.
It may run for n season or two, and oven, we admit bo very
popular. There is much that is striking and brilliant in the
dialogue of this play. The scenery we must not otnit to state,
was most gorgeous. Seldom indeed have we seen anything
on the stage more perfect than the laying out of the drawing
room of Lord Pompion.—Morning Chronicle, & Standard.
Mr. Webster has produeod a good and successful comedy.
" Old Heads and Young H farts® has mot with the most full
and decided success. " Old Heads and Young Hearts" is a
pleasing and promising title, and fortunately it does not
promise more than is performed. What wo like about (his
play is, that it does not partake of the heartless tone of the
mongrel, frivolous kind of drama which we have half-borrowed, half-imitated, from the French. There is a great
deal of good English " heart" in it, which does not beat exclusively in the young bosoms of the piece ; for the youngest
heart (that is, the warmest) among them all is conjoined with
the oldest head, in the person of Mr. Rural, the country Clergyman—a sketch in which sweetness, pathos, and Jiumonr are
combined in a manner worthy of Goldsmith. Excellent dialogue, solid as well as brilliant, smart, playful, Satirical, and
indicating knowledge of human nature. This play deserves
its succes.—John Bull.
Bourcicault's comedy is drawing capital houses, and moreover it deserves to draw them. We saw it on the first and on
the fourth nights, and it was astonishing to witness the improvement that h.s been made in that short interval. Not only
were all the performers at home in their characters, but same
small pieces had been cutout which were evident excrescences, and the diologne ran with unusual spirit and closeness of
repartee. W e are sure that it will be a lasting favorite with
ilay-goers, and we rejoice to seo them so numerous. Soma
lave complained that the two hist acts are not quite so good
as the three first; we dispute the position, but it: is of course
necessary to give an author a little time to unwind the intricacies of bis plot, and the plot of the new comedy is here and
there considerably involved. W e do not scruple to say that it
is perha ps the best comedy of modern times.and wo only wonder that it did not gain Webster's priee of £500.—Observer,
Mr. Bourcicnult's new comedy, " Old Heads and Young
Hearts," was decidedly and deservedly successful. It is^a
legitimate comedy, full of situation, equivoque, and fun, with
a very smart and lively dialogue, a little sentiment, and a good
deal of wit. It never Hags Tor a moment, and when it is orer
you say that it will quite bear being seen again.—Age & Argus.

f

We would fain have a proof now and then that invention,
constructive power, wit, repartee, have not yet wholly deserted
the young writers of England; and sometimes, though at long
intervals, we have evidence that these qualities are yet to be
found. They are all to be found, for instance, in the Comedy
of " Old Heads and Young Hearts," from the pen of Mr. D .
Bourcicault, produced last night at this Theatre, and as a consequence, it was completely successful. The dialogue is fre.
and flowing, sprightly, and at no time dull. Only premising
farther that the applause was warm and coidial during the first
act, that it was well and equally sustained throughout the other
three, and came to a close with enthusiasm at the end of the
fifth. The piece is admirably brought out; the scenery is excellent—those of the boudoir and the suite of drawing-rooms
are perfect in their way. Altogether its success must be gratifying both to the author and the management. The performers were called before the curtain to receive the applause of t h .
audience for their efforts, and were thanked by the cheers gf %
house crowded to excess.—Sun.
The acting of this Comedy deserves a particular n o t i c , - - Dramatic and Musical Review.
A more perfect triumph could not be coveted by author o r
manager, surrounded by a galaxy of talent of which no other
boards can boast, to the achievement of a grand and permanent
success. Together with the public we cordially rejoice that
this successful play has fallen into the hands of Mr. Webster,
Who deserved the best specimen of the legitimate drama, not
only for his industry in forcing, but for his supplying such a
hot-house of artistic talent to acclimatise the plants of British
genius. May our hearts ever be young enough, and our head,
never too old, to relish the fruit of good writing and good
acting conjoined in the new comedy at the Haymarket.—Era,
HAYMARKET.—"Old Heads and Young Hearts," (from,
the pen of Bourcicault), which made its entree to public life
at the Haymarket Theatre, on last Monday evening, with a
degree of eclat that must have satisfied author, manager,
actors, and every person interested in its success. The sparkling fire of repartee, and variety of incident, never allowed the
attention of the audience to be withdrawn for a moment. I t
commences well, and proceeds through the greater part of the
three fir«t acts with remarkable ease and increasing interest ;
at the commencement of the fourth act the author threw in a
fresh stock of embarrassments-und mistakes, which the concluding scene of the fifth act triumphantly redeems, and t h e
curtain descends amidst a torrent of "veil deserved applause.
The characters of the comedy are all drawn with vigour, and
some of them with great originality. W e have but rarely
witnessed a scene on the stage so replete with natural p a t h o .
as that in which Tom discovers (hat Lady Alice loves h i .
brother. The piece hod full justice done to it by all the performers ; the mise en scene, too, was in choice taste. The suite
of drawing-rooms in Lord Pompion's house, with the assembled company, was a beautiful and perfect realisation of the
subject in all its parts. The applause at the fall of the curtain was most enthusiastic.—Sunday Times.
" Old Heads and Young Hearts" was triumphantly successful, and went with roots of applause from beginning to end.
The comedy will run as long, and prove as great a favorite a s
Mr. Bourcicault's first production, " London Assurance."—
Railway Bell.
" Old Heads and Young Hearts" is tho very best thing that
has appeared for years—an assertion possibly borne eut by i t .
triumphant success. The writing was sparkling and pungent;
the portrayal of character natural and unaffected ; and in the
scenes of society introduced, nothing was outraged bv ignorance of t h . class from which they were drawn. The comedy
went with continued bursts of cheering, until the curtain fell
amidst a whirlwind of applause.—Illustrated London News,
A more warm and sincere impulse than that which, at the
fall ef the curtain on Monday night, actuated a crowded house
in successively calling forth the author, the manager, and the
performers, could not have been wished for by each and all,—
Great Gun.
The play opens with great spirit, and the whole of the first
act, amid nil the difficulty of introducing the characters, is excellent. The sccond.third and fourth nets ensue.and are marked
throughout by a number of very smart sayings and pithy observations, which would do credit to the true class of comedy,
and were deservedly taken and much applauded, — Literary
Gazette.
We congratulate Mr. Webster on his new piece of " Old
Heads and Young Hearts, and Mr. Bourcicault upon t h e
triumph he has achieved; certain it is that it is very clever
and something more—it is very successful.—Dispatch.

. I I I L L I E N ' S O R I G I N A L P O L K A , and ( 3 r d T i m e )

J I L L I E I ' i N E W MARURM-A, (Published by JULTAEN.)

Wo say of Mr. Dion Bourcicault's Comedy of • Old
Heads and Young Hearts' produced last night, that it is the
most amusing five-act production that has been see., for years,
and that it has pleased—honestly pleased, the public to a degree that may defy the exertions of any opposing theorist to
dispute its claim to popularity. His piece is carefully written
tkroughout, and he has introduced points in his dialogue, which
are worthy of any author. The author has thrown himself
with full zeal upon his writing, and has pushed along the dialogue with a buoyancy of spirit, liveliness, and brilliancy, which
completely carry an audience along in spite of themselves.
The curtain descended amid a perfect roar of applause. No
drama could have been more successful, and we must say the
success v>as fully deserved. The author hns produced a work
that has more elements of popularity than any of equal length
that we have seen for a long, long time. The actors played as
well as the most fidgctty dramatist would desire, and the decorative part has been most liberally managed bv Mr. Webster,
who received a marked acknowledgment on his entrance.—
The Times, and Weekly Chronicle.
Here we have a Comedy of real English growth, and with
a right hearty old English title. We must now, in jnstiee,
record the no less palpable merit of the author—his dialogue
in which he, with an affluence almost reckless, dispenses
antithesis, repartee, metaphor, simile, and pathos, with n
facility and a brilliancy that awakened many an echo of
boisterous laughter and hearty applause; nothing interrupted
the continuous explosions of laughter and plaudits which
reached their climax whan Mr. Farren upon joining the hands
of the lovers, uttered the following valedictory lines, with a
touching tenderness and truth which found their response in
evory breast:—"Bless your young faces." Sec.
The comedy
vr.ie very equally acted.—Morning Pott.
Applause and laughter were frequent during the evening,
and the curtain fell amid a hurricane ol cheers. Every scene
contains somo unexpected turn, ingeniously contrived. There
is considerable advance for the better in the tone of this
comedy. The comedy is put splendidly upon the stage, and
nothing, in short, hns beon spared in the wny of scenic
embellishment.—Morniny Herald.
It may run for a season or two, and oven, we admit be very
opulnr! There is much that is striking and brilliant in the
ialogue of this piny. The scenery wo must not omit to state,
was most gorgeous. Seldom indeed have we seen anything
on the stage more perfect than the laying out of the drawing
room of Lord Pompion.—Murniny Chronicle, & Standard.
Mr. Webster 1ms produced a good and successful comedy.
" Old Heads and Young Hearts has met with the most ftill
and decided success. " Old Iliads and Young Hearts'' is a
pleasing and promising title, and fortunately it does not
promise more than is performed. What wo like about this
play is, that it does not partake of the heartless tone of the
mongrel, frivolous kind of drama which we have half-borrowed, half-imitated, from the French. There is a great
deal of good English " heart" in it, which does not beat exclusively in t h . young bosoms of the pieeo ; for the youngest
heart (that is, the warmest) M O M them all is conjoi.ed with
the oldest head, in the person of Mr. Kurul. the country Clergyman—n sketeh in which sweetness, pathos, and humour urs
combined in a manner worthy of Goldsmith. Excellent dialogue, solid as well as brilliant, smart, playful, satirical, and
indicating knowledge of human nature. This play deserves
its aucces.—John null.
Bourcicault's comedy is drawing capital houses, ami moreover it deserves to draw them. We saw it on the first and on
the fourth nights, and it wns astonishing to witness t h . improvement that has been made in that short interval. Not only
were all t h . performers at home in their characters, but some
small pieces had been cut ont which were evident excrescences, and the dialogne ran with unusual spirit and closeness of
repartee. W e are sure that it. will be a lasting favorite with
play-goers, and we rejoice to see them so numerous. Some
have complained that the two last acts are not quite so good
as the three first; we dispute the position, but it is of course
necessary to give an author a little time to unwind the intricacies of his plot, and the plot of the new .omedy is here and
there considerably involved. W e do not scruple to say that it
is perhaps the best comedy of modern times,nnd we only wonder that it did not gain Webster's prize of £500.—Observer.
Mr. Boiircienult's now comedy, " Old Heads and Young
Hearts," was decidedly and deservedly successful. It is a
legitimate comedy, full of situation, uquivoque, and fun, with
Jt very smart and lively dialogue. • little sentiment, and a good
deal of wit. It never flags for n moment, and when it is over
you any that it will quite bear being seen again.—Age. & Argus,

I

We would fain have a proof now and then that invention,
constructive power, wit, repartee, have not yet wholly deserted
the young writers of England; and sometimes, though at long
intervals, we have evidence that these qualities are yet to be
found. They are all to be found, for instance, in the Comedy
of " Old Heads and Young Hearts," from the pen of Mr. D.
Boureicault, produced last night at this Theatre, and as a consequence, it was completely successful. The dialogue is free
and flowing, sprightly, and at no time dull. Only premising
farther that the applause was Mann and coidial during the first
act, that it was well and equally sustained throughout the other
three, and came to a close with enthusiasm at the end of the
fifth. The piece is admirably brought out; the scenery is excellent—those of the boudoir and the suite of drawing-rooms
are perfect in their way. Altogether its success must be gratifying both to the author and the management. The performers were called before the curtain to receive the applause of the
audirnee for their efforts, and were thanked by the cheers of a
house crowded to excess.—Sun.
The acting of this Comedy deserves a particular notice.—•
Dramatic and Musical Review.
A more perfect triumph could not be coveted by author or
manager, surrounded by a galaxy of talent of which no other
boards can boast, to the achievement of a grand and permanent
success. Together with the public we cordially rejoice that
this successful play has fallen into the hands of Mr. Webster,
rtbo deserved the best specimen of the legitimate drama, not
only for his industry in forcing, but for his supplying such a
hot-house of artistic talent to acclimatise the plants of British
genius. May our hearts ever be voung enough, and our heads
never too old, to relish the fruit of good writing and good
acting conjoined in the now comedy at the Huymnrket.—Era.
MAYMARKHT.—"Old Heads and Young Hearts," (from
the pen of Boureicnult), which made its entree to public life
at the Haymarket Theatre, on last Monday evening, with a
degree of eclat that must have satisfied author, manager,
actors, and every person interested in its success. The sparkling fire of repartee, and variety of incident, never allowed the?
attention of the audience to be withdrawn for a moment. I t
commences well, and proceeds through the greater part of th*
three first acts with remarkable easo and increasing interest;
at the commencement of the fourth act. the author threw in a
fresh stock of embarrassments and mistakes, which the concluding scene of the fifth act triumphantly redeems, and the
curtain descends amidst a torrent of well deserved applause.
The characters of the comedy are all drawn with vigour, and
some of them with great originality. W e have but rarely
witnessed a scene on the stage so replete with natural pathoa
as that in which Tom discovers that Lady Alice loves his
brother. The piece had full justice dona to it by all the performers ; tho mise en seethe, too, was in choice taste. The suite
of drawing-rooms in Lord Pompion's house, with the assembled company, was a beautiful and perfect realisation of the
subject in all its parts. The applause at the fall of the curtain was most enthusiastic.—Stenday Times.
" Old Heads and Young Hearts'' was triumphantly successful, and went with roars of applnuso from beginning to end.
The comedy will run as long, and prove as great a favorite as
Mr. Boureieoiilt's first production, " London Assurance."—
Railway Bell.
" Old Heads and Young Hearts'' is tho very host thing that
has appeared for years-—an assertion possibly borne out by its
triumphant success. The writing wns sparkling and pungent;
tho portrayal of character natural and unaffected ; and in the
scenes of society introduced, nothing was outraged by ignorance of the class from which they were drawn. The comedy
went with continued bursts of cheering, until the curtain fell
amidst a whirlwind of applause.—Illustrated London News.
A more warm and sincere implike than that which, at the
fall of the curtain on Monday night, actuated a crowded house
in successively calling forth the author, the manager, and the
performers, could not have been wished for by each and all.—
Great Gun.
The play opens with great spirit, and the whole of tho first
Mt. amid all the difficulty of introducing the characters, ia excellent. The second,third and fourth acts ensue,and are marked
throughout by a number of very smart sayings and pithy ob— '

OPINIONS of the PRESS.

W c say of M r . Dion Bourcicault's Comedy of ' Old
H e a d s and Y o u n g H e a r t s ' produced last night, fliat i t is t h e
m o s t amusing five-act production that lias been seen for years,
a n d t h a t it has pleased—honestly pleased, the public t o a d e T e e t h a t may defy t h e exertions of a n y opposing theorist t o
d i s p u t e its claim t o popularity. H i s piece is carefully written
t h r o u g h o u t , and h e has introduced p o i n t s in his dialogue, which
are worthy of any author. T h e a u t h o r has t h r o w n himself
with full zeal upon h i s writing, and has pushed along t h e dialogue with a buoyancy of spirit, liveliness, and brilliancy, which
completely carry an audience along in spite of themselves.
T h e curtain descended amid a perfect roar of applause. N o
d r a m a could have been m o r e successful, and we m u s t say t h e
success was fully deserved. T h e a u t h o r h a s produced a work
t h a t has more elements of popularity t h a n any oi equal length
t h a t we have seen for a long, long time. T h e actors played as
well a s t h e most fidgetty dramatist could desire, and t h e decorative p a r t has been m o s t liberally managed by M r . W e b s t e r ,
who received a marked acknowledgment on h i s entrance.—
The Times, and Weekly
Chroniele.
H e r e w e have a C o m e d y of real English g r o w t h , and with
a right hearty old E n g l t i n title. W e m u s t now, in j u s t i c e ,
r e c o r d t h e no less palpable merit of t h e author—his diulogne
in which h e , with nn affluence almost reckless, dispenses
a n t i t h e s i s , repartee, m e t a p h o r , simile, and p a t h o s , with «
facility and a brilliancy that awakened ninny an e c h o of
b o i s t e r o u s l a u g h t e r a n d hearty applause j nothing interrupted
t h e continuous explosions of laughter and plaudits which
r e a c h e d their climax when Mr. Farren upon joining the hnnds
of t h e lovers, uttered t h e following valedictory lines, with a
t o u c h i n g tenderness and truth which found their response in
every b r e a s t : — " B l e s s \ our y o u n g faces." &c.
T h e comedy
K I I I very equally acted.—Morning Post.
A p p l a u s e and l a u g h t e r were frequent during t h e evening,
and t h e curtain fell amid I hurricane of C h e e r s . Every scene
contains some unexpected MINI, ingeniously contrived. T h e r e
is considerable advance for t h e better in t h e tone of this
comedy.
T h e comedy is put splendidly upon t h e s t a g e , and
n o t h i n g , in short, h a s been spared in t h e way of scenic
embellishment.—Morning Herald.
It, may r u n for a season or t w o , and even, we admit b e very
p o p u l a r . T h e r e is much that is striking and brilliant in t h e
d i a l o g u e of this plnx. T h e scenery we must not omit to state,
w a s most g o r g e o u s . Seldom indeed h a v e W« seen a n y t h i n g
On t h e s t a g e more perfect than t h e laying out of t h e d r a w i n g
room of Lord Pompion.—Morning Chronicle, ft Standard.
M r . W e b s t e r bus produced a good and successful comedy.
*' Old H e a d s and Y o u n g Hearts bus met frith the m o s t full
a n d decided success. •' Old H e a d s a n d Y o u n g H e a r t s " is a
p l e a s i n g a n d promising title, and fortunately it doe* Not
p r o m i s e more than is performed. W h a t w e like a b o u t this
piny is, that it does n o t partake of t h e h e a r t l e s s tone of t h e
m o n g r e l , frivolous kind of drama which w e have half-borr o w e d , hnlf-hnitnted, from t h e F r e n c h . T h e r e is a g r e a t
d e a l o f g o o d English " h e a r t " in it, which doas not boat e x clusively m the y o u n g bosoms of t h e piece ; for t k e y o u n g e s t
heart (that is, the warmest) a m o n g them all is conjoined with
t h e oldest head, in t h e person of Mr. Rural, tha country C l e r g y m u n — a sketch in which s w e e t n e s s , p a t h o s , and h u m o u r a r e
c o m b i n e d in a manner worthy of Goldsmith. Excellent dial o g u e , solid a s well a s brilliant, smart, playful, satirical, and
indicating k n o w l e d g e of human n a t u r e . T h i s play deserves
its succcs.—John Unit,
Bourcicault's comedy is d r a w i n g capital h o u s e s , and moreover it deserves to draw them. W e saw it on t h e first and on
the fourth n i g h t s , and it was a s t o n i s h i n g to witness t h e imp r o v e m e n t that has been made in that short interval. Mot only
w e r e all t h e performers at. home in their characters, b u t some
small pieces had been c u t o u t which w e r e evident excrescences, a n d t h e dialogne ran with unusual spirit and closeness of
r e p a r t e e . W e a r e s u r e that It will b e a lasting favorite with
p l a y - g o e r s , and wo rejoice to see them s o n u m e r o u s . S o m e
h a v e complained t h a t t h e t w o last acts a r e not quite so good
as t h e three first; we dispute the position, but il is of course
necessary to give nn author a little time t o unwind t h e intricaoiMOi his plot, and the plot of the new eoniedy is here and
there considerably involved. W e do not scruple t > say that it
is p e r h a p s the best comedy of modern times, and we only wonder t h a t it did not gain W e b s t e r ' s prize of L'.'JOO.—Observer,
I M r . Bourcicuult's n e w comedy, " O l d H e a d s and Y o u n g
H e a r t s , " w a s decidedly a n d deservedly successful. I t is a
l e g i t i m a t e comedy, full of situation, equivoque, and fun, with
a very smart and lively dialogue, a little sentiment, and a g o o d
deal of wit. I l never flags for a moment, and when it is over
you say that it will quite bear being seen a g a i n , — A g e tk Argus.

W e would fain have a proof n o w and then that i n v e n t i o n ,
constructive power, wit, repartee, have not yet wholly deserted!
t h e young writers of E n g l a n d ; a n d sometimes, though a t l o n g
intervals, we have evidence that t h e s e qualities are y e t t o b e
found. T h e y are all to b e found, for instance, in t h e C o m e d y
o f " O l d Heads and Y o u n g H e a r t s , " from t h e p e n of M r . D .
Bourcicault, produced last night a t this T h e a t r e , and as a c o n s e q u e n c e , i t was completely successful. T h e dialogue is free
and flowing, sprightly, and a t n o t i m e dull. Only premising
farther t h a t the applause was warm and cot dial during the first
act, that it was well and equally sustained throughout t h e o t h e r
three, and came to a close with enthusiasm a t the end of t h e
fifth. T h e piece is admirably b r o u g h t o u t ; t h e scenery is excellent—those of the boudoir and t h e suite of d r a w i n g - r o o m s
a r e perfect in their way. Altogether its success m u s t b e g r a t i fying both t o the a u t h o r and t h e management. T h e performers were called before t h e curtain to receive (he applause of t h e
audience for their efforts, and were thanked by the cheers of a.
house crowded to excess.—Si'n.

T h e ncting of this Comedy deserves a particular n o t i c e . —

Rerieir.

m a n a g e r , surrounded by a galaxy of talent of which n o o t h e r

s u c c e s s . T o g e t h e r with t h e public w e cordially rejoice t h a t
this successful play h a s fallen into t h e hnnds of Mr. W e b s t e r ,
rt h o deserved the best specimen of the legitimate d r a m a , n o t
only for his industry in forcing, b u t for h i s supplying s u c h •
h o t - h o u s e of artistic talent t o acclimatise t h e plants of British:

never t o o old, t o relish t h e fruit, of g o o d writing and g o o d

H A V M A R K E T . — " O l d Heads a n d Young Hearts," (from
t h e p e n of B o u r c i c a u l t ) , w h i c h m a d e its entree to public* life
at t h e H a y m n r k e t T h e a t r e , o n last M o n d a y evening, with *
d e g r e e w eclat that must have satisfied author, m a n a g e r ,
actors, a n d every person interested in its success. T h e s p a r k ling fire of repartee, and variety of incident, never allowed t h e
attention of t h e audience to be withdrawn for a m o m e n t . I t
c o m m e n c e s well, and proceeds t h r o u g h t h e g r e a t e r part of t h e
three first acts with r e m a r k a b l e ease a n d increasing interest ;
a t t h e commencement o f t h e fourth n e t t h e a u t h o r t h r e w in a
fresh stock of embarrassments and m i s t a k e s , which t h e c o n c l u d i n g scene o f the fifth a c t triumphantly r e d e e m s , and t h e
curtnin d e s c e n d s amidst n torrent of well deserved a p p l a u s e .
T h e c hnracters of the c o m e d y a r e all d r a w n with vigour, a n d
some of t h e m with g r e a t originality. W e have b u t rarely
witnessed a scene on t h e s t a g e so replete with natural p a t h o .
as that in which T o m discovers that I.edy Alice loves h i .
b r o t h e r . T h e piece h a d full justice d o n e to it b y all t h e p e r formers ; t h e mise en scene, too, was in ohoico taste. T h e s u i t e
of d r a w i n g - r o o m s in L o r d P o m p i o n ' s h o u s e , with the a s s e m bled c o m p a n y , w a s n beautiful a n d perfect realisation of t h e
subject in a l l its ports. T h e applause a t t h e full of t h e c u r tain was most enthusiastic.—Sunday Time*.

OPINIONS of t h e PRESS.

" Old H e a d s and Y o u n g Hearts,' 5 l>y Mr. Dion Bourcit oult,
w a s produced at this theatre last nig-lit frith tlie most entire
and unqualified success. I t is full of amusing' i n c i d e n t a n d
lively bustle which never allow the interest in t h e d e v e l o p ment of the plan and story of the play to ring. T h e dinlogue
is remarkable for what is called " smartness ;" it frequently
rises into the brilliant and sparkling-, and DO w h e r e limps or
h a n g s fire. Every j o k e mid sarcasm c a m e as a decided hit,
and t h e laughter and applause which followed them were
both hearty and spontaneous. Tlie c h a r a c t e r s were, m o r e over, all individually well drawn a n d nicely contrasted, and
the parts were strongly cast. T h e piece closes with t h e
m a r r i a g e of t h e lovers in the most a p p r o v e d form, mid t h e
curlain fell amid a perfect furor of a p p l a u s e . T h e scenery
and dresses weru very splendid. N o t h i n g could he in better
taste than Lord P o m p i o n ' s drawing-room. T h e piece will
doubtless have a long run.—Globe.
T b e comedy is p u t splendidly upon t h e s t a g e , and may b e
pronounced perfectly successful.—Belts Weekly
Messenger.
Every scene produced something u n e x p e c t e d , a n d very
cleverly contrived.—Court Gazette.
T b e Haymarket is a t length set u p with a new comedy
t h a t is likely to attract for a time. Old H e a d s and Y o u n g
H e a r t s h a s hit the taste o f t h e town.
Smartly written,
cleverly performed, and handsomely p u t on t h e stage—»
vivacious enough t o b e entertaining— this Inst production of
M r . Bourcicault was received with acclamations on t h e first
n i g h t . I t is written u p to comedy pilch.—The Spectator.
T h a t long-sought philosopher's stone, a five-act comedy,
h a s at. length been found ; Mr. W e b s t e r is t h e fortunate
discoverer. T h e M u s e , that would n o t b e bribed with t h e
t e m p t i n g purse of Cue hundred golden g u i n e a s , has, of h e r
o w n free-will, granted the thing wanted
M r . Dion Bourcicault is the favored agent through whom s h e h a s made this
present t o the world. ' Old Heads and Y o u n g H e a r t s ' is t h .
name of this dramatic p r o d i g y ; which, t h o u g h haply many
imbued with very critical prejudices may dispute its title to
t h e n a m e , we mnst. in j u s t i c e pronounce it t o h e a legitimate
comedy. T h e r e is within it that sterling stuff of t h e head, if
not of the heart, which qualifies it to take its station a m o n g s t
our standard dramas. T h e characters a r e developed with
g r e a t skill; t h e l a n g u a g e i s sparkling a n d vivacious; t h e
cast of characters having been a s s t r o n g a s it possibly could
be, and t h e mise-en-scene
being most admirable, it w a s
entirely and unequivocally successful. Plaudits, l o n g and
loud anil universal, denoted that the seal of public approval
bnd been set upon it. T h e greatest praise is undoubtedly due
t o M r . W e b s t e r for his selection of thia successful comedy,
and for the liberal manner in which h e h a s produced it. I t
is likely to have an immense run.—Court Journal.
W e may a t once say t h a t t h e success of t h e p i e c . w a s
most complete and decided. Old H e a d s and Y o u n g H e a r t s
h a s earned its appellation. Mr. Bourcicault's main stay h a s
b e e n equivoque, bon mot*, quaint views of t h e motives a n d
springs of fashionable life, and smart r e p a r t e e ; materials of
which h e has a great abundance at c o m m a n d , and uses them
very skilfully and pleasantly—sometimes rising even above
t h e refined witticisms of the School for Scandal, and rarely
falling below t h e broad drolleries of Colman's five-act
cviravngmiaiis.—Atlas.

Mr. Bourcicault, whose freshness of spirit delighted t h e
town when h e presented his London Assurance, produced a
new comedy here on Monday, under t h e title of Old Heads
and Young Heart*, and it met with decided success. W e
admit that much of the applause w a s elicited b j the acting,
and scenic a r r a n g e m e n t s ; but the play itself possesses t h e
elements of success : it is lively, witty, and amusing—full of
bustling incidents and dramatic effects. T h e applause given
to t h e n e w comedy was hearty and universal.—Bell's New
Weekly
Messenger.
Old H e a d s and Young H e a r t s w a s played for the second
time last night, and again received with rapturous applause
by a crowded audience. W e have much pleasure to affirm
that it is very excellently written, and will a d d much t o t h e
author's reputation as a dramatist. I t evinces a most uecurate
k n o w l e d g e of stage effect. 7 he comedy is admirably b r o u g h '
out, and t h e performers excited themselves t o t h e u t m o s t .
T h e comedy, we «re certain, will have a long and prosperous
eareer.— Theatrical
Observer.
T h e production of n e w a n d original pieces is so laudable
to a managerial attempt, that Mr. W e b s t e r deserves every e n c o u r a g e m e n t for his efforts t o develop living and native
talent, a n d gratify the public by presenting them with d r a m a s
that, being of t h e time, reflect the time, and show the body
of t h e a g e , its form and p r e s s u r e . I n subservience to this
end, the comic m u r e is, p e r h a p s , the most available in itself,
and ceitainly the best adopted to the resources of the H a y Market T h e a t r e . N o w h e r e else can comedy b e s o well
represented. ' O l d Heads and Y o u n g H e a r t s piepared t h e
play-goer for antithesis and repartee in t h e dialogue, and
strong contrasts in the characters.
W e w e r e heartily g l a d ,
however, that t h e audience recognized t h e m a n a g e r s g o o d
intentions, and justified the applause with which t h e curtain
eventually fell on the new play.— The
Athencrum.
T h e pretensions of t h e comedy a n d its author, in t h i s
instance, seem, t o depend, in a very g r e a t d e g r e e ,
on the dialogue, and to this w e are disposed willingly t o
accord no stvall amount of merit. H i s dialogue is s n o w y ,
superficial, occasionally brilliant.
H e surprises and pleases
too, by a happy allusion or pointed p h r a s e . T h e audience
were kept skilfully in suspense till t h e very close. T h e
performers exerted themselves zealously to secure the success
of t h e ploy, a n d this they undoubtedly achieved.
As a
whole it went off well, a n d w a s uproariously applauded a t
the conclusion. T h e piece is admirably produced, and h a s
every adventitious appliance fitted to aid in giving reality and
effect to every scene. W e feel bound to add that the r e p o r t
we hear of it* nightly reception since, warrants t h e belief
that it will have a run that will repay the m a n a g e r for its p r o duction ; while the acting of such performers as are e n g a g e d
in it must ensure t h e development of w h a t e v . r merit it
possesses.—Satirist.
W h a t e v e r n a m e is given t o t h e entertainment in five a c t s
produced h e r e , its reception d o e s not admit of doubt. I t i s
greatly successful. W e did not see it until Thursday, w h e n ,
in despite and defiance of t h e fog, we foand t h e enjoyment
of a largo audience clear a n d indisputable. Laughter w a s
hearty and unrestrained, and the curtain fell t o peals of p r o longed a p p l a u s e . T h e a r r a n g e m e n t s of t h e scene are all in
the best possible t a s t e . — E x a m i n e r .

" Old Heads and Y o u n g Hearts,*' by Mr. Dion Bourcicault,
w a s produced a t this theatre last night with t h e most entire
and unqualified success. I t is full of amusing incident and
lively bustle which never allow t h e interest in t h e d e v e l o p m e n t of the plan and story of the play to flng. T h e dialogue
is rernarknble for what is called " smartness ;" it frequently
r i s e , into the brilliant and sparkling, and n o where limps or
h a n g s fire. Every j o k e antl sarcasm came as a decided hit,
and t h e laughter and applause which followed them were
b o t h hearty and spontaneous. T h e characters were, moreover, nil individually well drawn and nicely contrasted, and
the parts were strongly cast. T h e piece closes with t h e
m a r r i a g e of t h e lovers in the most approved form, and t h e
curtain fell amid a perfect furor of applause. T h e scenery
and dresses were very splendid. N o t h i n g could b e in better
t a s t e than Lord Pompion's drawing-room. T h e piece will
d o u b t l e s s have a l o n g run.—Globe.
T h e comedy is p u t splendidly upon t h e stage, and may b e
pronounced perfectly successful.—Belts II Kkly
Messenger.
Every scene produced something unexpected, and very
cleverly contrived.— Court Gazette.
T h e Haymarket is at length set u p with a new comedy
t h a t i t likely t o atlract for a time. Old H e a d s and Y o u n g
H e a r t s h a s hit t h e taste of t h e town.
Smartly written,
cleverly performed, and handsomely p u t on t h e s t a g e —
vivacious enough to b e entertaining— this last production of
Mr. Boureicault was received with acclamations on t h e first
n i g h t . I t is written u p to comedy pitch.—The Spectator.
T h a t l o n g - s o u g h t philosopher's stone, a fho-uct comedy,
h a s a t length been found ; Mr. W e b s t e r is t h e fortunate
discoverer. T h e M u s e , that would n o t b e bribed with t h e
t e m p t i n g purse of five hundred golden guineas, h a s , of h e r
o w n free-will, granted the thing wanted. Mr. Dion Boureicault is the favored a g e n t through whom she h a s m a d e this
present to the world. ' Old H e a d s and Y o u n g H e a r t s ' is the
n a m e of this dramatic prodigy ; which, though haply many
imbued with very critical prejudices may dispute its title to
t h e n a m e , we must in justico pronounce it to lie a legitimate
comedy. There is within it that sterling stuff of the head, if
not of the heart, which qualifies it to take its station amongst
our standard dramas. T h e characters are developed with
g r e a t skill; t h e l a n g u a g e is sparkling and vivacious; t h e
cast of characters having been a s s t r o n g as it possibly could
be, and t h e mise-en-scene
b e i n g most admirable, il was
entirely and unequivocally successful. Plaudits, long and
loud and universal, denoted that the seal of public approval
had been set upon it. T h e greatest praise is undoubtedly due
t o Mr. W e b s t e r for his selection of this successful comedy,
and for the liberal manner in which h e h a s produced it. It
is likely to have a n immense run.— Court Journal.
W e may at once say that the success of the piece w a s
most conn lete and decided. Old H e a d s and Y o u n g Hearts
h a s earned its appellation. Mr. Boureicault's main stay h a s
b e e n equhu/vc, bon mots, quaint views of t h e motives and
springs of fashionable life, and smart r e p a r t e e ; materials of
which h e has a groat abundance at command, and uses them
very skilfully and pleasantly—sometimes rising even above
t h e refined witticisms of the School for Scandal, and rarely
falling below t h e broad drolleries of Colman's five-act
extravaganzas —Atlas.

Weekly
Messenger.

Observer.
T h e production of n e w and original pieces is so laudably
to a managerial attempt, that Mr. W e b s t e r deserves every e n c o u r a g e m e n t for his efforts to develop living and native
talent, and gratify the public by presenting them with d r a m a s
that, b e i n g of the time, reflect the time, and show the b o d y
of the a g e , its form and pressure. I n subservience to this
end, the comic muse is, perhaps, the most available in itself,
and certainly the best a d a p t e d to the resources of t h e H a y Market T h e a t r e . N o w h e r e else can eomedy b e s o well
n p n s e n t e d . ' Old H e a d s and Y o u n g H e a r t s prepared t h e
play-goer for antithesis and repartee in t h e dialogue, a n d

Whatever name is given to t h e entertainment in live a c t s
produced here, its reception does not admit of doubt. I t i s
greatly successful. W e did not see it until Thursday, w h e n ,
in despite and defiance of the fog, we found t h e enjoyment
of a l a r g e audience clear and indisputable. Laughter w a s
hearty and unrestrained, and the curtain fell t o peals of p r o longed applause. T h e arrangements of t h e s e e n , are all in
the best possible t a s t e . — E x a m i n e r .

Mr. Ec iircie ault. whose freshness of spirit delighted t h e
town when h e presented his Londm Assurance, produced a
new comedy here o n M o n d a y , under t h e title of Old H'ads
and Young Heaits, and it m e t with decided success. W e
admit that much of the applauso w a s elicited by the a c t i n g ,
and teenic a r r a n g e m e n t s ; but the play itself possesses t h e
elements of success ; it is lively, witty, and amusing—full of
bustling incidents and dramatic effects. T h e applause given
to t h e n e w comedy vvus hearty and universal.—BelTs New
Weekly
Messenger,
Old H e a d s and Y o u n g H e a r t s w a s played for the second
time last night, and again received with rapturous applause
by a crowded audience. W e have much pleasure t o affirm
that it is very excellently written, and will add much to t h e
author's reputation as n dramatist. It evinces n most a c c u r a t e
k n o w l e d g e of stage effect. 'J he comedy is admirably b r o u g h '
out, and t h e performers excited themselves to t h e u t m o s t .

the best possible t a s t e . — E x a m i n e r .

" Old H e a d s and Y o u n g Hearts,"' by Mr. Dion Bourcicault,
was produced at this theatre last n i g h t with t h e most entire
and unqualified success. I t is full of amusing incident a n d
lively hustle Which never allow t h e interest in t h e d e v e l o p m e n t of the plan and story of the play to flag. T h e dialogue
is remarkable for what is called " smartness ; - ' it frequently
rises into the brilliant and sparkling, a n d n o where limps o r
h a n g s tire. Every j o k e ana sarcasm came as a decided hit,
and t h e laughter ami applause which followed them were
both hearty and spontaneous. T h e characters were, moreover, a l l individually well drawn a n d nicely contrasted, and
the parts were Strongly cast. T h e piece closes with t h e
m a r r i a g e of t h e lovers in the most approved form, a n d t h e
curtain fell amid a perfect furor of applause. T h e scenery
and dresses were vetv splendid. N o t h i n g could b e in better
taste than Lord P o m p i o n ' s drawing-room. T h e piece will
doubtless have a long run.—Globe.

W e may a t once say that t h e success of t h e piece was
most complete and decided. Old Heads mid Young Hearts
h a s earned its appellation. Mr. Bourcicault's maiu stay h a s
been equivoque, ban mots, quaint views of t h e motives a n d
springs of fashionable life, and smart r e p a r t e e ; materials of
which he lias a s t o a t abundance at command, and uses them
very skilfully and pleasantly—-sometimes rising even above
t h e refined witticisms of the School for Scandal, and rarely j
falling below t h e broad drolleries' of Column's five-act
extravaganzas.—Atlas.

T h e pretensions of t h e comedy a n d its author, in this
instance, seem, t o depend, in a very g r e a t dee-re.,
on the dialogue, and to this w e a r e disposed willingly t o

superficial, occasionally brilliant.
H e surprises and pleases
too, by a happy allusion or pointed phrase. T h e audience
were kept skilfully in s u s p e n s e till t h e very close. T h e
performers exerted themselves zealously to secure t h e success
of t h e play, a n d this they undoubtedly achieved.
As a
whole it went off well, a n d w a s uproariously applauded a t
the conclusion. T h e piece is admirably produced, and h a s
every adventitious appliance fitted to aid in giving reality and
effect to every scene. W e feel b o u n d to add that the report
we hear of its nightly reception since, warrants t h e belief
that it will have a run that will repay the m a n a g e r for its p r o duction ; while the acting of such performers a s are e n g a g e d
in it must ensure t h e development of whatever merit it
possesses.—Satirist.

h a s at length been found ; M r . W e b s t e r is t h e fortunate
discoverer. T h e Muse, that would not b e bribed with t h e
tempting' purse of live hundred golden g u i n e a s , has, of h e r
o w n free-will, granted t h e thing wanted. M r . Dion Bourcicuult is t h e favored a g e n t through whom s h e h a s made this
present to the world. ' Old H e a d s and Y o u n g H e a r t s ' is the
name of this dramatic prodigy ; which, t h o u g h haply many
imbued with WrTJf critical prejudices may dispute its title t o
the name, we roust in j u s t i c e pronounce it t o be a legitimate

great skill; t h e l a n g u a g e is sparkling and vivaoious ; t h e
cast of characters having boen a s s t r o n g as it possibly could

entirely a n d unequivocally successful. Plaudits, long a n d

viad been set upon it. T h e greatest praise i t undoubtedly due

and lor tho liberal manner in which h e h a s produced it. I t
i* likely to have an immense run.— Court
Journal.
VVo may a t once say that t h e success of the piece w a s

Mr. Bouroieault, whose freshness of spirit delighted t h e
town when h e presented his Londtn As&urance, produced a
new comedy here on Monday, under t h e title of Old Heads
and Young Heaits, and it mot with decided success. W e
admit that much of the applause was elicited by the acting,
and scenic a r r a n g e m e n t s ; but t h e play itself possesses t h e
elements of success : it is lively, witty, and amusing—full of
bustling incidents and dramatic effects. T h . applause giveh
to t h e n e w comedy was hearty a n d universal.—BelTs New
Weekly
Messenqer.
Old Heads and Y o u n g H e a r t s w a s played for the second
time last night, and again received with rapturous applaus*
by a crowded audience. W e have much pleasure to affirm
that it is very excellently written, and will a d d m u c h t o t h e
author's reputation as a dramatist. I t evinces a most accurate
k n o w l e d g e of stage effect. 1 he comedy is admirably b r o u g h t
out, and the performers everted themselves t o t h e utmost.
T h e comedy, w* are certain, will have a long and prosperous
career.— Theati ical Observer.
T h e production of new a n d original pieces is so laudable
to a mnnas'erial attempt, that Mr. W e b s t e r deserves every e n couragement for his efforts t o develop living and native
talent,and gratify the public by presenting them withdram a s
that, being of tlie time, reflect t h e time, and show the body
of the a g e , its form and pressure. I n subservience to this
end, the comic muse is, p e r h a p s , t h e most available in itself,
and certainly the best a d a p t e d to t h e resources of t h e H a y Market T h e a t r e . N o w h e r e else can OPtO.dj b e s o well
represented. ' O l d Heads a n d Y o u n g Hearts prepared t h e
p l a y g o e r for antithesis a n d repartee in t h e dialogue, and
strong contrasts in the characters.
W e were heartily glad,
however, that t h e audience recognized t h e m a n a g e r ' s good
intentions, and justified t h e applause >rith which t h e curtain
eventually fell on the new p l a y . — The
Alhenteum.
T h e pretensions of t h e comedy a n d its author, in this
instance, seem, t o depend, in a very g l e e t degree,
on the dialogue, and to this w e are disposed willingly to
accord no small amount of merit. H i s dialogue is snowy,
superficial, occasionally brilliant.
H e surprises and pleases
too, hv a happv allusion or pointed phrase. T h e audience
were kept skilfully in suspense till t h e very close. T h e
performers exerted themselves zealously t o secure the success
of t h e play, a n d this they undoubtedly achieved. A s a
whole it went off well, a n d w a s uproariously applauded at.
the eonclnsi.n. T h e piece is admirably produced, and h a s
every adventitious appliance fitted to aid in giving reality and
effect to every scene. W e feel h o n n d to add that the report
we hear of its nightly reception since, warrants t h e belief
that it will have a run that will repay the mnnager for its p r o duction ; while t h e acting of such performers as are e n g a g e d
in i t must ensure t h e development of whatever merit it
possesses.—Satirist.
Whatever name is given to t h e entertainment in five acts
produced h e r e , its reception d o e s not. admit of d o u b t . I t is

in despite and defiance of t h e fog, we found t h e enjoyment,

the best possible taste.—Examiner,

~MXAJJEPTE».

" Old H e a d s ai.d Young- H c n i t s , ' ' by Mr. Dion B o u r c k a u l t ,
was produced at this theatre Inst night with the most entire
mid unqualified success. I t is full of amusing incident a n d
Hf.li bustle which never allow t h e interest in (he d e v e l o p ment of the plnn nnd story of the piny to flag-. T h e dinlogue
is reinarkuble for what is'called " smartness ;" it frequently
rises into the brilliant nnd sparkling, and BO w h e r e limps or
h a n g s 6 r e . E v e r y j o k e and sarcasm c a m e as a decided hit,
and (lie laughter and a p p l a u s e which followed them w e r e
both hearty and spontaneous. Tlie characters were, m o r e over, nil individually t e l l drawn and nicely c o . t r a s t e d , and
the parts were strongly cast. T h e piece closes with t h e
marriage of t h e lovers in the most approved form, and t h e
curtain fell amid a "perfect furor of applause. T h e scenery
and dresses were very splendid. N o t h i n g could he in better
taste than Lord Pom'pion's drawing-room. T h e piece will
d o u b t l e s s have a l o n g run.—Globe.

A N E W & ORIGINAL COMEDY, in Five Acts,

HEADS

T h e comedy is put splendidly upon the s t a g e , nnd may b e
pronounced perfectly successful.—Belt's Weekly
Messenger.
Every scene produced something unexpected, a n d very
cleverly contrived.— Court Gaxelte.
T h e Hnymnrket is at length ?et u p with a new comedy
that is likely to attract for a time. Old H e a d s and Y o u n g
H e a r t s h a s hit t h e taste of t h e town.
Smartly written,
cleverly performed, and handsomely p u t on t h e s t a g e —
vivacious e n o u g h to h e entertaining— this last production of
Mr. Uouicioniilt was reccived with acclamations on t h e first
night. I t is written up to comedy pitch.—The Spectator.
That l o n g - s o u g h t philosopher's stone, a five-act comedy.
lias at length been found ; Mr. W . b s t e r is t h e fortunate
discoverer. T h e Mnso, that would n o t b e bribed with t h e
t e m p t i n g purse of live hundred golden g u i n e a s , has, of h e r
o w n free-will, granted the thing wanted
M r . Dion Boureicault is the favored a g e n t through whom s h e h a s m a d e this
present to the world. * Old Heads and Y o u n g Hearts' is the
name of this dramatic prodigy ; which, t h o u g h haply many
imbued with very critical prejudices may dispute its title t o
the n a m e , we must in j u s t i c e pronounce it t o T e a legitimate
comedy. T h e r e is within it that sterling stufTof the h e a d , if
not of the heart, which qualifies it to tuke its station a m o n g s t
our standard dramas. T h e characters a r e developed with
g r e a t skill; t h e l a n g u a g e is spnikling and vivacious; t h e
cast of characters having been a s s t r o n g as it possibly could
be, and t h e miee-en-scene
being most admirable, it w a s
entirely and unequivocally successful. Plaudits, long- a n d
loud and universal, denoted that the seal of public approval
had been set Upon it. T h e greatest praise is undoubtedly due
to Mr. W e b s t e r for his selection of this successful comedy,
and for the liberal manner in which h o h a s produced it. I t
is likely to h a v . an immense run.— Court
Journal.

B K N N K T T.

W e may a t once say that t h e success of the pieee w a s
most complete nnd decided. Old H e a d s and Y o u n g H e a r t s
has earned its appellation. Mr. Bourcicault's main stay h a s
been tqtlivcqut. bon mots, quaint views of tho motives a n d
springs of fashionable life, and smart r e p a r t e e ; materials of
which h e bus a great abundance at command, and uses them
very skilfully aud pleasantly—sometimes rising- even a b o v e
t h e refined witticisms of the School for Scandal, and rarely
falling below the broad drolleries of Colman's five-act
extravaganzas.—Alias.

T H E COUHTESS O F POMPION s BOUDOIR.

TheSUTTEof DRAWING ROOMS

Mr. Bourcicnult, whose freshness of spirit delighted t h e
town w heii h e presented his LmtdtM Assurance, produced a
new comedy here on M o n d a y , under t h e title of Old Hfads
and Yoting Heaits, and it met with decided success. W e
admit that much of the applause w a s elicited by the acting,
and scenic a r r a n g e m e n t s ; but (he play itself possesses t h e
elements of success ; it is lively, witty, nnd amusing—full of
bustling-incidents and dramatic e l e c t a . T h e applause given
to t h e n e w comedy was hearty nnd u n i v e r s a l . — B e l t s New
Weekly
Messenger.
Old H e a d s and Y o u n g H e a r t s w a s played for the second
time last n i g h t , and again received with rapturous applause
by a crowded audience. W e have much pleasure to affirm
that it is very excellently written, and will a d d much to t h e
author's reputation as a dramniist. It evinces a most accurate
k n o w l e d g e of stage effect. T h e comedy is admirably b r o u g h t
out, nnd t h e performers exerted themselves t o t h e u t m o s t .
T h e comedy, we are certoin, will have a long and prosperous
career.— Theatrical
Observer.
T h e production of n e w nnd original pieces is so laudable
to a mniinsrerial attempt, that Mr. Webster deserves every e n couragement for his efforts to develop living- and native
talent, and gratify the public by presenting them with dram a s
that, being- of t h e time, reflect t h e time, and show the body
of the a g e , its form and pressure. I n subservience to this
end, the comic mil?e is, p e r h a p s , the most available in itself,
and certainly the best adapted to the resources of the H a y Market T h e a t r e . N o w h e r e else can c o m e d y b e s o well
r e p i e s e n t . d . ' O l c T H e a d s and Y o u n g Hearts' prepared t h e
plny-goer for antithesis and repartee in t h e dialogue, «nd
strong contrasts in the charocters.
W e w e t e heartily g l a d ,
however, that t h e audience recognized the manager s good
intentions, a n d justified the applause with which t h e curtain
eventually fell on the new p l a y . — The
Athexeeum.
T h e pretensions of t h e comedy f-iid its cuthor, in this
instance, seem, t o depend, in a very g r e a t d e g r e e ,
on the dialogue, and to this w e a r e disposed willingly to
accord no small amount of merit. H i s dinlogue is showy,
superficial, occasionally brilliant. H e surprises and pleases
too, by a happy allusion or pointed p h r a s e . T h e audience
were kept skiffully in suspense till t h e very close. T h e
peiformers exerted themselves zeolously to secure the success
of the iplay, a n d this they undoubtedly achieved.
As a
whole it went off well, a n d w a s uproariously applauded a t
the conclusion. T h e piece is admirably p r o d u . e a , and h a s
every adventitious appliance fitted to aid in g i v i n g reality and
effect to every scene. W c feel bound to add that the report
we hear of its nightly reception since, warrants t h e belief
that it will have n run that will repay the m a n a g e r for ita p r o duction ; while the acting of such performers a s are e n g a g e d
in it must ensure t h e development of whatever merit it
possesses.—Satirist.
Whatever n a m e JN given to t h e entertainment in five acts
produced h e r e , its reception d o e s not admit of doubt. I t is
greatly successful. W e did not see it until Thursday, when,
in despite and defiance of the fog, we found t h e enjoyment
of a large audience clear a n d indisputable. L a u g h t e r was
hearty and unrestrained, and the curtain fell to peals of prolonged applause. T h e a r r a n g e m e n t s of the scene are all in
the best possible t a s t e . — E x a m i n e r .

OPINIONS of the PRESS.
" Old H e a d s and Y o u n g H c a i t a , " by Mr. Dion Bourdoaujt,
Wa. fiioduc(>fl nt this theatre last night with t h e most entire
and uitqualiftcd success. It is full of amusing incident a n d
lively hustle which never allow t h e interest in t h e development of t h e plan and HOT) <>f t h e piaj to fin;; Tin dialogue
is remarkable for wltal is cnlled " s m a r t n e s s ;" it frequently
Tises into t h e brilliant and sparkling, a n d n o w h e r e limps o r
h a n g s fire. Every joke and sarcasm ram. M a decided hit,
and the laughter and applause, which followed them were
both hearty and • p o n t a n . o o s . 5 f c . d w f . c t e n were, m o r e over, all individually well d A w n and nicely contrasted, and
the parts w e r e W o o g l y cast. T h e piece closes with t h e
marriage of t h e lovers in t h e moat approved form, and t h e
curtain fell amid n perfect furor of applause. T h e s t e n c r v
and dresses were very splendid. N o t h i n g could be in better
ta^te than L o r d P o m p i o n ' s drawing-room. T h e p i c e will
doubtless b a s e a long run.— Globe.
T h e comedy is put splendidly upon t h e s t o g e , and m a y b e
pronounced perfectly Hucceasful,—Bell's Weekly
Metsenyer.
Every scene produced something unexpected, and veiv
cleverly contrived.—Court Cazetle.
T h e Maymarket it nt length set u p with a n> « comedy
that is lilcely t o atlract for a time. Old H e a d s and Young
H e a r t s has hit t h e taste ol t h e town,
(smartly written,
cleverly performed, and bnndsomel\ put on t h e s t a g e —
•Wacious e n o u g h to be e n t e r t a i n i n g - this lust production of
M r . B o u r c i e . t t h Was received with acclamations o n t h e first
night. It is written tin to comedy pitch.—The Spectator.
That l e n g - s o u g h t philosopher's stotro, » five-acl comedy,
il length been found ; M r . W e b s t e r is t h e fortunate
discoverer. T h e M u s e . t h a t would not b e bribed with t h e
tempting purse of live hundred golden g u i n e a s , h a . , of her
Own free-will, granted t h e tiling wanted
M r . Dion B o n n ioault is the favored agent t h r o u g h whom s h e has made this
present to t h e world. ' Old H e a d s and Y o u n g Hearts 1 is the
name of this dramatic prodigy ; which, t h o u g h haply manyimbued with very critical prejudices may dispute its title t o
the name, we must in justice pronounce it to be a legitimate
comedy. T h e r e is within it that sterling stuff of t h e head, if
not of the heart, which qualifies it to take its station amongst
our standard drumas. T h e characters a r e developed with
g r e a t s k i l l ; t h e l a n g u a g e i s sparkling and vivacious; t h e
cast of characters having been a s s t r o n g as it possibly could
b e , and t h e misc-en-scene
b e i n g most admiraole, it w a s
entirely a n d unequivocally successful. Plaudits, long a n d
loud and universal denoted that t h e seal of public approval
bad been set upon it. T h e greatest praise is undoubtedly due
to Mr. Webstw 1 for Ins selection of this successful comedy,
and lor t h e liberal manner in which h e has produced it. It.
is likely to have an immense run.—Court
Journal.

W e may at once nay that tin success of the piece w a s
roost complete and decided. Old Heads and Young Hearts
lias earned its appellation. Mr. Boureicault'a main stay has
b e e n equivoque, hon pot*, quaint views of t h e motives' a n d
springs ol fashionable life, and smart r e p a r t e e ; materials of
which he has a great abundance at command, and uses them
very skilfully and pleasantly—sometimes rising even above
t h e refined witticisms of the School for Scandal, and rarely
falling below t h e broad drolleries of Colman's five-act
extravaganzas.Atlas.

Mr Bouicieault, whose freshness of spirit delighted t h e
t o w n when lie presented his London Assurance, produced n
new comedy here on Monday, u n d e r t h e title of Old Heads
and Young Heatti,
and it met with decided success. W «
admit that much of the applause was elicited by t h e a c t i n g ,
and scenic a r r a n g e m e n t s ; but t h e play itself possesses t h e
elements of success ; it is lively, witty, and amusing—full of
bustling incidents and dramatic effects. T h e applause given
to t h e n e w comedy was hearty a n d universal -Heirs
New
Weekly
Messenger.
Old H e a d s and Y o u n g H e a r t s w a s played for the second
time last night, and again received with rapturous a p p l a u s e
by a crowded audience. W e have much pleasure to affirm
that it is very excellently written, and will add much t o t h e
author's reputation as a dramatist. It evinces a most accurate
knowledge of s t a g e effect. T h e comedy is admirably b r o u g h t
out, and the performers exerted themselves to t h e u t m o s t .
T h e comedy, we a r e certain, will have a long and prosperous
career.—Theatrical Observer.
T h e production of new a n d original pieces is so laudable
to a managerial attt nipt, that Mr. W e b s t e r deserves every e n couragement for his efforts t o develop living and native
talent, and gratify the public by presenting them with d r a m a s
that, being of trie time, reflect t h e time, and show t h e b o d y
of the age, its form and p r e s s u r e . I n subservience to this

and certainly t h e best adapted to the resources of t h e H a y Market T h e a t r e . N o w h e r e else c a n comedy b e s o weH
represented.

The pretensions of t h e comedy a n d its author, in thia
instance, seem, t o depend, in a very g r e a t d e g r e e ,
on t h e dialogue, and to this w e r.re disposed willingly t o

superficial, occasionally brilliant.
H e surprises and please?
too, by a happy allusion or pointed phrase. T h e audience
were \ e p t skilfully in suspense till t h e very close. T h »

A« a
whole it went off well, a n d was uproariously applauded a t

TIME.

" Old H ^ a d s and Y o u n g Hearts,"' by Mr. Dion Bourcienult,
WHS produced (it this theatre lust night with die most entire
and unqualified success. I t is full of amusing incident nnd
lively hustle which n e \ c r allow t h e interest in t h e development of t h e plun and story of the play to flag. T h e dialogue
is remarkiihle for what is (ailed " smartness ;" it frequently
rises into the brilliant and sparkling, mid no where limps or
Jiangs fire. Every j o k e and sarcasm m i n e as a decided hit,
nnd t h e laughter and applause which followed them were
both hearty and s p o n t a n e o u s . T h e characters were, m o r e over, all individually well drawn and nicely contrasted, and
the parts were strongly cast. T h e piece closes with t h e
marriage of t h e lovers in the most approved form, and the
curtain tell amid n perfect furor of applnuse. T h e scenery
and dresses were very splendid. Nothing could he in Better
taste than Lord Pompion's drawing-room. T h e piece will
doubtless have a long run.—(llohe.
T h e comedy is put splendidly upon the s t a g e , and may b e
pronounced perfectly successful.—BelTs 11'eekhj Mexseni/er.
Kverv S K I I C produced something unexpected, and very
cleverly contrived.— Court Gaxelte.
T h e }ln\ market is at length set Up with a new < omnlv
that is likely to attract for n time. Old Heads and Y o u n g
H e a r t s J u s hit the taste of t h e town.
Smartly written,
cleverly performed, a n d handsomely p u t on t h e s t a g e —
vivacious enough to he entertaining— this last production of
Mr. Boureicault was received with acclamations on the first
n i g h t . It is written up to comedy pitch.—The Spectator.
That long-sought philosopher's stone, a five-act comedy,
h a s at length been f o u n d ; Mr. W e b s t e r is t h e fortunate
discoverer. T h e M u s e , t h a t would not b e bribed with t h e
t e m p t i n g purse of live hundred golden g u i n e a s , has, of h e r
o w n free-will, granted the thing wanted
M r . Dion Boureicault is t h e favored a g e n t through whom she lias m a d e this
present to the world. ' Old H e a d s and Y o u n g H e a r t s ' is the
n a m e of this dramatic prodigy ; which, t h o u g h haply many
imbued with very critical prejudices may dispute its title t o
t h e n a m e , we must in justice pronounce it t o be a legitimate
comedy. T h e r e is within it that sterling stuff of t h e heud, if
not of t h e heart, which qoalifiw it t o take its station a m o n g s t
our standard dramas. T h e characters a r e developed with
great skill-; t h e l a n g u a g e is sparkling and vivacious ; t h e
cast of characters having been a s s t r o n g as it possibly could
be, a n d t h e mtu ttt~tCHM being most admirable, it w a s
entirely and unequivocally successful. Plaudits, long and
loud and universal, denoted that the seal of pnhlic approval
had been set upon it. T h e greatest praise is undoubtedly due
t o Mr. W e b s t e r for his selection of this successful comedy,
and for the liberal manner in which h e has produced it. I t
is likely to hav> an immense run.—Court Journal.
W e may at once say that the success of the piece w a s
most complete and decided. OKI H e a d s and Young Hearts
lias earned its appellation. Mr. Boureioault's main stay has
been equivoque, htm mots, quaint views of t h e motives a n d
springs oI fashionable life, and smart repartee ; materials of
which he has a g ' e a t abundance at. command, and uses them
very skilfully ami pleasantly—sometimes rising even above
t h e refined witticisms of t h e School for Scandal, nnd rarely
falling below t h e broad drolleries of m Column's five-act
extr ivae.inzas.—Alias.
