Mr. Bourcicault, whose freshness of spirit delighted t h e
town when h e presented his London Assurance, produced a
new comedy here on Monday, under t h e title of Old Heads
and Young Jfeaits,
and it met with decided success. W e
admit (la.t much of the a p p l a u s e was elicited by the acting,
and scenic a r r a n g e m e n t s ; but the play itself possesses t h e
elements of success ; it is lively, witty, and amusing—full of
bustling incidents and dramatic effects. T h e applnuse given
to t h e new comedy was hearty and universal.—BelTs New
JVeekly
Messenger.
Old H e a d s and Y o u n g Hearts was played for t h e second
time last niglit, and again received with r a p t u r o u s applause
by a crowded audience. W e have much pleasure to affirm
that it is very excellently written, and will add much to the
author's reputation as a dramatist. I t evinces a most accurate
k n o w l e d g e of stage effect. T h e comedy is admirably brought
out, and the performers exerted themselves to the utmost.
T h e coinedv, * • are certain, will have a long and prosperous
Career.— Thea/riral
Observer.
The production of new a n d original pieces is so laudable
to a managerial attempt, that Mr. \ \ ebster deserves every en
c o n n g e n i e n t for his efforts to develop living and native
talent,and giatifv the public by presenting them w i t h d r a m a s
that, being of t h e time, reflect the time, and show the body
of the a g e , its form and pressure. I n subservience to this
end, the comic muse is, p e r h a p s , the most available in itself,
and certainly the best a d a p t e d to the resources of the H a y Market T h e a t r e . N o w h e r e else can comedy be so well
represented. ' O l d H e a d s and Y o u n g H e a r t s prepared t h e
play-goer for antithesis nnd repartee in t h e dialogue, and
strong contrasts in the characters.
W e were heartily glad,
however, that t h e audience recognized t h e m a n a g e r ' s good
intentions,and justified the a p p l a u s e with which the curtain
eventually fell on the new play.— The
Athend'um,
T h e pretensions of t h e comedy and its author, in this
instance, seem, to depend, in a very g r e a t d e g r e e ,
on t h e d i a l o g u e , and to this w e a r e disposed willingly t o
accord no small amount of merit. H i s dialogue is showy,
superficial, occasionally briHievt.
H e surprises and pleases
too, by a happy allusion or pointed p h r a s e . T h e audience
were kept skilfully in suspense till t h e very close. T h e
performers exerted themselves zealously to secure the success
of t h e play, a n d this they undoubtedly achieved.
As a
whole it went off well, a n d was uproariously applauded a t
the conclusion. T h e piece is admirably produced, and h a s
every adventitious appliance fitted to aid in giving reality and
effect to every scene. VVe feel bound to add that the report
we hear of its nightly reception since, warrants t h e belief
that it. will have a run that will repay the m a n a g e r for its production ; while the acting of such performer* as are e n g a g e d
in it must ensure t h e development of whatever merit it
possesses.—Satirist.
W h a t e v e r name is given to the entertainment in five acts
produced here, its reception does not admit of doubt. It is
greatly successful. W e did not see it until Thursday, when,
in despite and defiance of t h e fog, we found t h e enjoyment
of a l a r g e audience clear and indisputable. Laughter was
hearty and unrestrained, and t h e curtain fell t o peals of prolonged a p p l a u s e . T h e a r r a n g e m e n t s of t h e scene are all itl
the best possible t a s t e . — E x a m i n e r .

OPINIONS of t h e PRESS.

" Old H e a d s and Y o u n g H e a r t s / ' by Mr. Dion Boureieault,
w a s produced a t this theatre last night with the m o s t entire
and unqualified success. I t is full of a m u s i n g incident a n d
lively bustle which never allow t h e interest in t h e development of t h e plan and story of the play to flag. T h e dialogue
is remarkable for what is called " smartness ;" it frequently
rises into t h e brilliant and sparkling, and n o w h e r e limps o r
b a n g s fire. E v e r y j o k e a n d sarcasm c a m e a s a decided hit,
and t h e laughter and npplouse which followed them were
both hearty and spontaneous. T h e characters were, moreover, all individually well drawn a n d nicely contrasted, and
t h e parts were strongly cast. T h e piece closes with t h e
marriage of t h e lovers in the most approved form, and t h e
curtain fell amid a perfect furor of a p p l a u s e . T h e scenery
and dresses were very splendid. N o t h i n g could be in better
taste than Lord Pompion's drawing-room. T h e piece will
doubtless have a long run.—Globe.
T h e comedy is put splendidly upon the s t a g e , and may b e
pronounced porfectlv successful.—Bell's Weekly
Messenger.
Every scene produced something unexpected, and very
cleverly contrived.—Court Gazette.
T h e Haymarket is a t length set u p with a new comedy
that is likely to attract for a time. Old H e a d s and Y o u n g
H e a r t s h - s hit t h e taste of t h e town.
Smartly written,
cleverly performed, and handsomely p u t on t h e s t a g e —
vivacious enough to be entertaining— this last production of
M r . Botircicniilt was received with acclamations o n t h e first
n i g h t . I t is written up to comedy pitch.—The Spectator.
T h a t l o n g - s o u g h t philosopher's stone, a five-act comedy,
fans at length been found ; M r . W e b s t e r is t h e fortunate
discoverer. T h e Muse, that would not b e bribed with t h e
tempting purse of five hundred golden g u i n e a s , has, of h e r
o w n free-will, granted the thing wanted
M r . Dion Bourcicault is the favored agent t h r o u g h whom s h e h a s made this
present to the world. ' Old H e a d s and Y o u n g H e a r t s ' is the
n a m e of this dramatic prodigy ; which, t h o u g h haply many
imbued with very critical prejudices may dispute its'title to
tile name, we m a s t in j u s t i c e pronounce it t o be a legitimate
comedy. T h e r e is within it that sterling stuff of t h e head, if
not of t h e heart, which qualifies it to take its station amongst
our standard dramas. T h e characters a r e developed with
g r e a t s k i l l ; t h e l a n g u a g e is sparkling a n d vivacious ; t h e
cast of characters having been a s s t r o n g as it possibly could
be, a n d t h e mise-en-scene
being most admirable, it w a s
entirely a n d unequivocally successful. Plaudits, long a n d
loud and universal, denoted that the seal of public approval
had beeu set upon it. T h e greatest praise is undoubtedly due
t o M r . W e b s t e r for his selection of this successful comedy,
and for the liberal manner in which h e h a s produced it. I t
is likely to have an immense run.—Court Journal.
W e may a t once say that t h e success of t h e piece w a s
roost complete and decided. Old H e a d s and Y o u n g Hearts
h a s earned its appellation. Mr. Bourcicatilt's main stay has
been equivoque, bon mots, quaint views of t h e motives a n d
springs o f fashionable life, and smart repartee;
materials of
which he h a s a great abundance at command, and uses them
very skilfully and pleasantly—sometimes rising even above
t h e refined witticisms of the School for Scandal, and rarely
falling below t h e broad drolleries of j Colman's five-act
extravaganzas.—Atlas.

Mr. Bourcicault, whose freshness of spirit delighted t h e
t o w n when h e presented his London Assurance, p r o d u c e d a
new comedy h e r e on Monday, under t h e title of Old Head*
end Young Hearts, and it m e t with decided success. W e
admit that much of the applause w a s elicited by t h e a c t i n g ,
and scenic a r r a n g e m e n t s ; b u t the play itself possesses t h e
elements of success : it is lively, witty, and amusing—full of
bustling incidents and dramatic effects. T h e a p p l a u s e given
to t h e n e w comedy was hearty a n d universal.—BelFs New
Weekly
Messenger.
Old H e a d s and Y o u n g H e a r t s w a s played for t h e second
time last n i g h t , a n d again received with rapturous applause
by a crowded audience. W e have much pleasure t o affirm
that it is very excellently written, and will a d d much to t h e
author's reputation as a dramatist. I t evinces a most accurate
k n o w l e d g e of s t a g e effect. T h e comedy is admirably b r o u g h t
out, and the performers exerted themselves t o t h e u t m o s t .
T h e comedy, we a r e certain, will have a long and prosperous
career.—Theatrical Observer.
T h e production of new a n d original pieces is so laudable
to a managerial attempt, that Mr. W e b s t e r deserves every en
couragement for his effort* t o develop living a n d native
talent, and gratify the public by presenting them with d r a m a s
that, being of t h e time, reflect tbe time, and show the body
of the a g e , its form and p r e s s u r e . I n subservience to this
end, the comic muse is, p e r h a p s , t h e most available in itself,
and certainly t h e best adapted to the resources of t h e H a y Market T h e a t r e . N o w h e r e else c a n comedy b e s o weH
represented. ( Old Heads a n d Y o u n g Hearts prepared t h e
play-goer for antithesis and repartee in t h e dialogue, and
strong contrasts in the characters.
W e were heartily g l a d ,
however, that t h e audience recognized t h e m a n a g e r s good
intentions, and justified the a p p l a u s e with which t h e curtain
eventually fell on the new p l a y . — The
Athenmum.
T b e pretensions of t h e comedy a n d its author, in this
instance, seem, t o depend, in a very g r e a t d e g r e e ,
on tbe dialogue, and to this w e a r e disposed willingly t o
accord n . small amount of merit. H i s dialogue is s h o w y ,
superficial, occasionally brilliant.
H e surprises and pleases
too, by a happy allusion or pointed phrase. T h e audience
were kept skiffully in suspense till t h e very close. T h e
performers exerted themselves zealously to secure the success
of t h e play, a n d this they undoubtedly achieved.
As a
whole it went olf well, a n d w a s uproariously applauded a t
the conclusion. T h e piece is admirably produced, and h a s
every adventitious appliance fitted to aid in giving reality and
effect to every scene. W e feel b o u n d to add that the report
we hear of its nightly reception since, warrants t h e belief
that it will have a run that will repay the m a n a g e r for its p r o duction ; while the acting of such performers a s are e n g a g e d
in it must ensure t h e development of whatever merit it
possesses.—Satirist.
W h a t e v e r n a m e is given to t h e entertainment in five acts
produced h e r e , its reception d o e s not admit of d o u b t . I t is
greatly successful. W e did not see it until T h u r s d a y , when,
in despite and defiance of t h e fog, we found t h e enjoyment
of a large audience clear a n d indisputable, l a u g h t e r w a s
hearty and unrestrained, and t h e curtain fell t o peals of prolonged a p p l a u s e . T h e a r r a n g e m e n t s of t h e scene a r e all in
the best possible t a s t e . — E x a m i n e r .

OPINIONS of the PRESS.

" Old H e a d s find Y o u n g H r n r t s , ' ' by M r Dion Bourcicault,
was produced nt ( M l theatre In^t night w h n the m o s t entire
and unqualified success. I t is full of a m u s i n g incident and
lively bustle which never allow the interest in t h e d e v e l o p ment of t h e plnn and story »f t h e play to ring. T h e d i a l r g u e
is remarkable lor whet is called '* smartness \" it frequently
rises into t h e brilliant and sparkling, a n d n o w h e r e limps or
h a n g s fire. E v e r y j o k e and sarcasm t a m e as a decided hit,
and t h e laughter and a p p l a u s e which followed them ware
both hearty and s p o n t a n e o u s . T h e characters were, m o r e over, all individually well drawn and nicely contrasted, and
t h e parts w e r e strongly eatjt. T h e piece closes with t h e
marriage of t h e lovers in t h e most approved form, and tlie
curtain fell amid a perfect furor of a p p l a u s e . T h e scenery
and dresses were verv splendid. N o t h i n g could b e in better
taste thnn Lord P o m p i o u ' s d r a w i n g - r o o m . T h e piece will
doubtless have a long run.—Glohe.

OPINIONS of the PRESS.

" Old H e a d s and Y o u n g H e a r t s , - ' by Mi' W o n Bourcieault,
was produced at this theatre last night with the m o s t entire
and unqualified success. I t is full of amusing' incident a n d
lively bustle which never allow t h e interest in t h e development of t h e plan and stoiv of tlie play to flag-. T h e dialogue
is remarkable for what is culled " smartness ;"' it frequently
rises into the brilliant and sparkling-, and no " h e r e limps or
h a n g s fire. E v e r y j o k e ami sarcasm came «s a decided hit,
and t h e laughter and a p p l a u s e which followed them were
both hearty and spontaneous. T h e characters were, moreover, all individually well drawn a n d nicely contrasted, and
the parts were strongly cast. T h e piece closes with t h e
marriage of t h e lovers ID the most approved form, and t h e
curtain fell amid a perfect furor of applause. T h e scenery
and dresses were very splendid. Nothing' could be in better
taste than L o r d P o m p i o n ' i drawing-room. T h e piece will
doubtless have a long run.— Globe.

Mr. Boiircicnult, whose freshness of spirit delighted t h e
town when h e presented his London Assurance, produced a
new comedy here on Monday, under t h e title of Old Head*
and Young Heaits,
and it m e t wit!: decided success. W e
admit that much of the applause w a s elicited by the a c t i n g ,
and scenic a r r a n g e m e n t s ; b u t the play itself possesses t h e
elements of success ; it is lively, witty, and amusing—full of
bustling incidents and dramatic effects. T h e applause given
to t h e n e w comedy was hearty a n d u n i v e r s a l . — B e l t s New
Weekly
Messenger.

time last n i g h t , and again received with rapturous applause
by a crowded audience. W e have much pleasure t o affirm
that it is very excellently written, and will add much to t h e
author's reputation as a dramatist. I t evinces a most accurate
knowledge of singe effect. 1 he comedy is admirably b r o u g h t
out, and the performers exerted themselves to t h e u t m o s t .

the parts were Itrongly cast. T h e piece i l e a ' s with the
marriage of the lovers in the most approved form, and the
curtain fell amid a perfect foror of autrfanae. T h e scenery
and dresses were very splendid. N o t h i n g could lie in bitter
taste than Lord I'ompion's drawing-room. T h e piece will
doubtless b a \ e a lonj> run.—(j/obe.

Tlie Hay market is at length set u p with a lew comedy
that is likely to attract for B t i n e . Old Heads and Young

< l e \ i r ! y performed, and handsomely p u t on t h e stage—

Tl at long-sought philosopher's StObe, a live-act comedy,
has at length been b u n d j Mr. W e b s t e r i^ the fortunate
discoverer. 'I he Muse, that would n o t b e bribed with t h e
tempting purse of live hundred golden guineas, has, of h e r
own free-will, granted the t h u g wanted
Mr. I>io;; Bourci
CHtllt is the l i m n e d agent through whom she h a s m a d e this
present to the World. ' Old n e a d t a n d Y o u n g Hearts" is the
name of this dramatic prodigy ; which, though haply many
imbued with very critical prejudices mav dispute" its title to
the name, we must in justice pronounce It to l e a legitimate
comedy. There is within it that sterling stud'of the head, if
not of the heart, which qualifies it to take its station amongst
our standard dramas. T h e characters are developed with
g r e a t skill; t h e l a n g u a g e is sparkling and vivacious; t h e
cast of characters having been a s strong as H possibly could
be, and the niise-m-scrne
being most ndmirarile, it was
entirely and unequivocally successful. Plaudits, long and
loud and dniver.al, denoted that the- seal of public approval
bad 1c en set upon it. T h e greatest praise is undoubtedly due
to Mr Webster for his selection of this successful comedy,
and !<r the liberal manner in which h e has produced it. It
is likely to have an immense run.— Court Journal.

Mr. Koure icault. whose freshneft* of >-piiil delighted t h e
t o w n when l.e presented his London Assurance, p r o d u c e d a
new corned) I i r e c n Mondav, under t h e title of Old H'-ad.f
and Young Heatli,
and it met with decided success. W e
admit that much of the applause w a s elicited by the acting,
and scenic a r r a n g e m e n t s ; but the play itself possesses t h e
elements of suet e s s : it is lively, witty, and amusing—full of
bustling incidents and dramatic effects. T h e applause given
to t y e n e w comedy was hearty and u n i v e r s a l . — B e l t s New
If 'etkly
Messenger.
T h e production of new and original pieces is so laudable
to n menstrerial altc mpt, that Mr. W e b s t e r deserves every e n
cotirageincnt (or his efforts to develop living and native
t a l e n t , a n d gratify the public b \ presenting them with dram as
that, being of the time, reflect the time, and show the body
of the a g e , its b u m tint! pressure. I n subservience t o this
end, the comic muse is, perhaps, the most available in itself,
mid certainly the best adapted to the resources of the H a y Market Theatre, N o w h e r e else can comedy be s o well
represented. ' O l d H e a d s and Y o u n g Hearts* prepared t h e
play-goer for antithesis and repartee in t h e dialogue, and
strong contrasts in the characters.
W e were heartily glad,
however, that t h e audience recognized the manager's good
intentions, and justitied t h . applause with which tlie curtain
eventually fell on the new p l s y — T l . c Athena-um.
T h e pretensions of t h e comedy a n d its author, in this
instance, seem, to depend, in a very great d e g r e e ,
on the dialogue, and to this w<> are disposer] willingly to
accord no s n a i l amount of merif. H i s dialogue i s s h o w v ,
superficial, occasionally brilliant.
H e surprises and pleases
too, by a happy allusion or pointed phrase. T h e audience
were k e p t skiifully in suspense (ill t h e very close. T h e
performers exerted themselves aealcusly to secure t h e s u c c e s s
of t h e play, and this they undoubtedly achieved.
As a
whole it w ent off well, and was uproariously applauded at
the conclusion. T h e piece is admirably produced, arM h a s
every adventilieus appliance fitted to aid in giving reality and
effect to e v e n scene. W e feel bound to add that the report
we hear of its nightly reception since, warrants t h e belief
that it will have a run that will repay the manager for its p r o duction ; while the acting of such performers as are e n g a g e d
in it must ensure t h e development of whatever merit it
possesses.—Satirist.
W h a t e v e r name is given to the entertainment in five acts
produced here-, its reception does not. admit of doubt. It is
ercatlv successful. V\ e did not see it until Thursday , when,
in despite and defiance of the fog, we found t h e enjoyment
of a l a r g e audience clear and indisputable. Laughter was
hearty and unrestrained, ami the curtain fell to peals of prolonged applause. T h e arrangements of the scene are all in
the best possible taste.— Examiner.

** Old H e a d s and Y o u n g H e a r t s , ' ' by Mr. Dion B o u r e k n u l t ,
w a s produced at this theatre Inst n i g h t vtitti the m o s t entire
and unqualified success. I t is full of amusing incident and
lively hustle which never allow t h e interest in t h e d e v e l o p m e n t of the plan and sfory of t h e piny to flag. T h e dinlogue
is remarkable for what is called " smartness ;" it frequently
rises into the brilliant and sparkling, and n o where Jimp* or
b a n g s fire. Every joke anil sarcasm t a m e as a decided hit.
and t h e laughter a n d applause which followed t h e m were
b o t h hearty and spontaneous. T h e characters were, moreover, all individual!;, well drawn a n d nicely contrasted, and
t h e parts were strongly cast. T h e piece closes with t h e
marriage of t h e lovers in the most approved form, and t h e
curtain fell amid a perfect furor of a p p l a u s e . T h e s c e n e n
and dresses were very splendid. N o t h i n g could be in better
t a s t e than Lord Pofltpion'a drawing-room. T h e piece will
doubtless have n long rim.— Globe.
Th<- comedy is p u t splendidly upon t h e l U n , <md may b e
pronoti!i"ed perfectly successful.— Bttti
Uefkly
Messenger,
Every scene produced something u r e v p e c t c d , a n d very
c l e \ e r l \ contrived,—Court Gazette.
T h e Hay market is a t length set u p vtith t new comedy
Mint is likely t o attract for a time. Old H e a d s and Y o u n g
H e a r t s h a s hit t h e taste of t h e town
Smartly written.
cleverly performed, and handsomely p u t on t h o s t a g e —
viviii ions enough to b e e n t e r t a i n i n g - this Inst production of
Mr. Boutcicault was received with acclamations on t h e first
n i g h t . It is written u p to comedy pitch.—The Spectator.
T h a t l e n g - s o u g h t philosopher's stone, a five-act com«dy,
h a s at length lieeu found . M r . W e b s t e r is t h e fortunate
discoverer. '1 h e M u s e , that would not b e bribed with t h e
t e m p t i n g purse of five hundred golden fiuinons, h a a ^ o f hei
o w n free-will, granted lha thing wanted, Mr. Dion Bourci
canlt is the favored agent through whom she h a s madi this
present lo the world. ' Old H e a d l a n d Young- Heart*' is t h e
n a m e of this dramatic prodigt ; which, though hnpl\ many
imbued with veiy critical prejudices n a y dispute its title t o
t h e name, we must in justice pronounce it t o b e a legitimate
comedy. There is within it that sterling stuff of t h e head, if
not of the heart, which qualifies it t o take its station amongst
our standard dramas. T h e characters a r e developed with
g r e a t skill; t h o l a n g u a g e is sparkling a n d v i v a c i o u s ; t h e
cast of characters having been a s s t r o n g a s it possibly could
be, and the mtee-en-icene
being most adnnrnrile, st w a s
entirely and unequivocally successful. Plaudits, long a n d
loud and universal, denoted that the seal of public approval
h a d been set upon it. T h e greatest praise is undoubtedly due
t o Mr. W e b s t e r for b i s teteetiofl of this successful comedy,
a n d for the liberal manner in which h e has produced it. I t
i* likely to have an immense run.— Court
Journal.

Mr. Bourcicault, whose freshness of spirit delighted t h e
t o w n when h e presented his London Assurance, p r o d u c e d a
new comedy here on Monday, under t h e title of Old Head*
and Young Heaits, a n d it met with decided success. W e
admit that much of the applause w a s elicited by t h e a c t i n g ,
and scenic a r r a n g e m e n t s ; but t h e play itself possesses t h e
elements of success ; it is lively, witty, and amusing—full of
bustling incidents and dramatic- effects. T h e applause g i v e n
to t h e n e w comedy was hearty a n d u n i v e r s a l . — B e l t s New
Weekly
Messenger.
T h e production of n e w a n d original pieces is so l a u d a b l e
to a managerial a t t e m p t , that Mr. W ebster deserves every en
c o u r a g e m e n t for h i s efforts to develop living and native
t a l e n t , a n d gratify t h e public by p r e s e n t i n g them with d r a m a s
that, being of t h e time, reflect t h e time, and show t h e b o d y
of t h e a g e , its form and pressure. I n subservience t o this
end, the comic muse is, perhaps, t h e most available in itself,
and certainly the best a d a p t e d to t h e resources of t h e H a y Market T h e a t r e . N o w h e r e else c a n comedy b e s o Weir
represented.
' O l d H e a d s and Y o u n g Hearts prepared t h e
play-goer for antithesis and repartee in t h e dialogue, and
strong contrasts in the characters.
W e were beart|lv g l a d ,
however, that t h e audience recognized t h e m a n a g e r ' s good
intentions, and justified the applause with which t h e curtain
eventually fell on the new play.— Thf Athenceum.
T h e pretensions of the comedy a n d its author, in this
instance, seem, t o depend, in a very great d e g r e e ,
on the dialogue, and to this w e a r e disposed willingly t o
accord no small amount of merit. H i s dialogue is s n o w y ,
superficial, occasionally brilliant.
H e surprises and pleases
too, by a happy allusion or pointed phrase. T h e audience
were kept skilfully in suspense till t h e very eloae. ' H i e
peiformers everted themaelvei zealously t o secure the success
ol t h e play, ami tins the) undoubtedly achieved.
As a
whole it went off well, a n d n n s uproariously applauded a t
the conclusion. T h e piec e It admirably produced, and h a s
c \ e r \ adventitious uppliniicc fitted to aid m giving reality and
effect to every scene. W e feel b o u n d t o add that the r e p o r t
we hear of its nightly reception since, warrants t h e belief
that it will h a w a run that will repay lhe> manager for its p r o duction ; while t h e acting- of such performers as are e n g a g e d
in it must ensure t h e development of whatever merit it
possesses.—Satirist.

W h a t e v e r n a m e is given to t h e entertainment in five acts
produced here, its reception does not admit of doubt. It is
greatly successful. W e did not see it until T h u r s d a y , w h e n ,
in despite and defiance of the fog, we found t h e enjoyment
of it l a r g e audience clear and indisputable
La'jghter washearty and unrestrained, and t h e curtain fell to peals of p r o longed applause. T h e arrangements of (he scene a r e nil in
the best possible t a s t e . — E x a m i n e r .

" Old Henils and Young- Hciitts,'' by Isr, W o n Botircicmilt,
UH!. iitf ilui-ed «t tlii"- tlientro last nijrlit wi11, the m o t t e n t i r e
nnil unqualified i u c e . M . It is lull of amusing incident unci
livelv b u i t l e which never alto") ibe interest in the derelof)roent of t h e (tliin atul storv of tlie piny to flog'. T h e dklogPU
ia remarkable lor vthiit is culled " smartness j " it frequently
rises into the brilliant and sparkling, and n o w h e n limps or
h o n g s fire. Every j o k e nnu sarrnsm c a m e as • decided hit,
and t h e laughter and applause, u h i c h followed them w e r e
both hearty and spontaneous. T h e characters u e r e , moreover, all Individually well drawn a n d nicely contrasted, and
the parts wete strongly cast. ' I h e piece closes with t h e
marriage of t h e lovers in t h e most approved form, and t h e
curtain fell amid a ptffi 11, furor of applause. *£%, sreiicrs
and dresses were very splendid. Nothing could lie in better
taste than Lord Pompion's dravung-room. T h e piece nill
doubtless have a long run.—Globe.
T h e comedv is put splendidly upon the s t a g e , and may be
pronounced perfectly successful.— Belt* Weelly
Messenger.
Every scene produced something in expected, am! w r y
i l e i e r l v contrived,— Cmirt Caxelte,
T h e Hn>market is a t length set iq> with a new conn d\
that is likely to attract for a time. Old H e a d s and Y o u n g
H e u r t s ha a hit t h e taste of t h e town.
Smartly written,
< Ii \erly | erfntmed, and handsomely put OS t h e s t a g e —
\ i i i n ions enough to b e cnteitaining- this last pr< dutliim of
Mr. Bomcicoult V I I received with acclamations on t h e first
n i g h t . I t is written uii to comedy pilch.— Thr P/wcla/or.
T h a t long-sought philosopher's stone, a lire-ail ( n m e d i ,
h a s a t length been f o u n d . M r , "Webster is t h e forluna'te
discoverer. T i e Muse, that would not b e bribed with t h e
tempting purse of live bundled golden guinea 1 ., has, of h e r
o w n free-will, gianted t i e thing IMrtttM
Mr. Dion B o a r d
cault is t h e favoicd agent through whom she h a s made this
present to the World, ' Old l l c a d s a n d Y o u n g H e a r t s ' is the
name of this dramatic prodigy ; which, t h o u g h haply many
imbued with very u i t i c a l prejudices may dispute its title t o
t h e n a m e , we must in justice pronounce it t o be a legitimate
comedy. T h e r e is within it that sterling stuff of t h e h e a d , if
not of the heart, which qualifies it to take its station amongst
our standard dramas. T h e characters are developed with
g r e a t skill; t h e l a n g u a g e is sparkling a n d vivacious ; t h e
cast of (hiiptetets having been a s s t r o n g as it possibly could
he. a i d t h e mise-rn-scene
being most admiranle, it w a s
entirely and unequivocally successful. Plaudits, long and
loud and universal, denoted that the seal of public approval
had been set Upon it. T h e greatest praise is undoubtedly due
to M r W e b s t e r for his selection of this successful comedy,
and for t h e liberal manner in which h e h a s produced it. I t
is like!v t o have an immense run.— Court
Journal.

Mr. Bourcicault, whose fieshness of spirit delighted t h e
town when b e presented his Londcn Assurance, produced a
new c< nicely h e r e o n M o n d a y , u n d e r t h e title of (XdHead*
itnd Young Heails, and it met will, decided success. W e
admit that much of the applause was elicited by the acting,
and scenic nrrangententeI but the piny itself possesses t h e
elements ol itteCCM ; it is lively, witty, and amusing—full of
bustling incidents and dramatic effects. T h e applause given
to t h e n e w comedv was heartv and universal.—Mttf$ JVSrM
Weekly
Messenger.
The production of new a n d original pieces is so laudable
to n managerial attempt, that Mr. W ebster deserves every en
coiirngement for his efforts to develop living and native
talent, and gratify the public by presenting them with dram a s
that, being of the time, reflect the time, and show the body
of t h e a g e , its form and pressure. I n subservience to this
end, rhe COIIIK muse is, perhaps, the most available in itself,
and certainly the best a d a p t e d to the resources of t h e H a v Market T h e a t r e . N o w h e r e else c a n comedy b e s o well
repiescnted. ' O l d H e a d s and Young H e a r t s ' p i e p a r e d t h e
pl»y-goer for antithesis and repartee in t h e dialogue, and
strong contrasts in the chorncters.
W e were heartily glad,
however, that t h e audience recognized t h e m a n a g e r ' s gcod
intentions,and justified the applause with which the curtain
eventually fell on the new play.- -The Athena-urn.

T h e pretensions of t h e comedy a n d its nuthor, in this
instance, seem, to depend, in a verv g r e a t d e g r e e ,
on the dialogue, and to this w e are disposed willingly to
accord n o so all amount of merit. H i s dialogue is showy,
superficial, occnsirc.-lly ! rilliaut.
H e surprises and pleases
too, by a happy allusion or pointed phrase. T h e audience
were kepi skilfully in suspense till t h e very close. T h e
performers evened themselves zealously to secure the success
of t h e play, a n d this they undoubtedly achieved.
As a
whole it went oil 'Well, a n d was uproariously applauded a t
the conclusion. T h e niece is admirably produced, and h a s
every adventitious appliance tilted to aid IB giving reality and
elleit to every scene. W e feel b o u n d to add that the report
we hear of its nightly reception since, warrants t h e belief
that it w ill have a run that will repay the m a n a g e r for its p r o duction ; while the acting of such performers a s are e n g a g e d
in it must ensure t h e development of whatever merit it
possesses.—Satirist.
W h a t e v e r name is given to t h e entertainment in five acts
produced h e r e , its reception does not admit of doubt. It is
greatly successful. W e did not see it until Thursday, when,
in des'pite and defiance of t h e fog, we found t h e enjoyment
of a l a r g e audience clear a n d indisputable. Laughter w a i
hearty and unrestrained, and t h e curtain fell t o peals of prolonged applause. T h e arrangements of t h e scene are all in
the best possible t a s t e . — E x a m i n e } .
